review_title: Stellar cast on paper, does not work in reality.
review_detailed_main:
I had great expectations for this. Great cast, Nicole Kidman, Joey King, Zac Efron and the always amazing Kathy Bates.

While on paper the casting is great, but when you watch this weak romcom it's easy to see that Efron and Kidman have been miscast. Either one would probably have worked very well with another actor but together Efron and Kidman are quite frankly, awful, in this. They have zero chemistry and to me looks like they couldn't even fake it. Their faces seem to lack the ability to portray any natural emotive expressions whatsoever. They are 100% not believable as lovers which makes it really impossible to root for their relationship.

Bates is her usual lovely self, and King is excellent, providing the only comic relief here. They completely carry this film.

Avoid.

review_title: Chemistry in all the wrong places
review_detailed_main:
It's a standardized, stale romance that pales in comparison to the recent "The Idea of You" which had a lot more charm, even when that movie wasn't amazing. But it felt a lot cuter than this one and Anne Hathaway made it a lot more believable.

In "A Family Affair" though, the chemistry is visible in the faces of the two main actors instead of between them. That only furthers the artificiality of it all.

The plot evolves in a predictable way, on the acting side there are no standouts and it's directed without much flair. It's astonishing that all the prominent names behind and before the camera agreed to make such a nothing of a movie.

review_title: Made an account just for this
review_detailed_main: I love senseless, silly rom cons. They are just fun escapes. They get a lot of hate, but I usually like them. I'm probably just immature or unsophisticated as a woman in my 50s. When I was just minutes into this, I thought 'what is wrong with their faces'? I wasn't surprised by Nicole because it's typical for woman in Hollywood, but I was surprised by how Zac looked who is still in his 30s. As others have written, both of their faces are very distracting. I came to the reviews to see if anyone was feeling the same way. I also agree that there is zero chemistry and the acting is subpar. I agree Kathy Bates is good and the daughter really carries the movie. Kind of painful to watch and I am very, very easy to please with rom cons.

review_title: chemistry was not chemistrying at all

review_detailed_main:
I love rom coms and enjoyed this light fun one on a Sunday morning having breakfast in bed.

Great acting from Kathy Bates and Joey King.

Horrific surgery from Nicole and Zac led to this being hard to watch. Nicole can't express with that face anymore. The chemistry between them was non existent.

I enjoyed the premise and we had a few laughs but I'm glad we didn't go to the cinema and drop coin on this movie.

Husband and I came straight to the reviews to see if everyone agreed with us and they do.

Please cast Kidman opposite someone her own age next time. I just really wish the surgery wasn't a thing. Age gracefully please people. It's painful to see.

What a cringe-fest of a movie - more plastic here than my local recycling plant !! The main characters are Brooke played by Nicole Kidman who has a very limited range of expressions these days and Chris played by Zac Efron with an equally small range of expression. Its hard to engage with characters that have very little chemistry or personality. Add to that the very dated plot of younger successful self-obsessed man falls for older woman who just happens to be the mother of his young female assistant played with girlish zeal by Joey King.

Veteran actor Kathy Bates as Brooke's mother in law does her best given the material she has to work with.

The love scenes between Brooke and Chris are cringe-worthy to watch as they both seem so awkward !

review_title: Average romcom that fell a little below expectations
review_detailed_main:
After seeing this advertised on the coming soon section of Netflix and the great cast line up I eagerly watched this on the day of release. While I'm glad I watched it, I would say it fell short of my expectations. The storyline is average and in parts a little messy. Some of the chemistry between characters feels a little too forced tho this could be down to how the script has been written rather than the actors capabilities. There was definitely atleast one scene I didn't feel worked at all and was a poor choice when written for the direction they wanted the storyline to go.

I wouldn't say this movie was absolutely awful, the actors do a great job in their respective roles with Joey King probably giving the best performance of the main leads. The ending was a little predictable and I could see where it was going to end up ahead of time. Not the worst watch, an average rom com at best. For me it wasn't enjoyable or memorable enough to make me want to rewatch in future so this will likely be a one time viewing.

review_title: I just don't understand the reviews. It was a fun movie
review_detailed_main:
I watched this yesterday and yes i know i am overall someone who is easy to please with movies. I am a movies fan, but a pop corn movies fan first. I don't mind a long intellectual movie once in a while but im the kinda guy who will have fun with a toilet humor Adam Sandler comedy.

But over my "leniance" toward movies, i don't get what the peoples complain here. I didn't notice such a "lack of chemistry" between Chris and Brooke. Maybe its because i watched in French but it was perfectly fine for me.

As for the plastic surgery that i read in so many other reviews... Well Nicole Kidman was doing movies i was a kid and i am almost 40. She is 57 ... For a woman her age, i think she looks great. I will admit Zac Efron does look a bit older than in my memories but then again the guy is 36 now, he ain't 20 something anymore. Sure i could pick up that he had some work done but it didn't distract me like some of these reviewers.

Overall the star was Joey King as Zara. Its her movie. I think she was great. Charismatic, cute, and i enjoyed the interactions with Chris.

As for the rest yeah its a bit as your usual romcom exept the focus this time ain't on the main character love story but her mom, but again is that an issue? You either like these movies or you don't. Personally i did.

I would give it a 7.5 out of 10 but due to the system i must settle on a 7 out of 10.

Idk. I thought it was a cute movie. Of course it's not a mind-bending thriller, or anything like that, but it was exactly the kind of movie that I was looking to watch on a slow day off; A cute love story to pass the time.

I'm not sure if it's because I didn't watch the trailer and just hit play, so I didn't really know what to expect from the story line, but I actually thought it was cute idea. The chemistry between Zac Efron and Nicole Kidman was palpable, so I feel they did a good job. And, although they made Zac Efron's character out to be a womanizer, I didn't feel like it was that far off or unbelievable: Insert Leonardo DiCaprio. Further, I absolutely love Kathy Bates in pretty much anything she does, and although she was a peripheral and predictable character, she still managed to bring a lot of life to her role. Zoey King... this wasn't a heavy weight movie by any means, but I definitely see her talent here. Especially when she hit her head after she caught her boss and mom together! So funny!

So, overall, I would recommend it. I wouldn't put too much emphasis on how "great" it was, because I always end up hating highly praised movies; they just never live up to the hype, but there have been so many other movies far worse than this one, like Lindsay Lohan's Irish Wish for example, that this one was was actually cute and I would say good.

Definitely give it a try!

Zac Efron has not had plastic surgery, he had a jaw reconstruction after a near fatal accident left him with his chin hanging off his face.

Nicole Kidman is pushing 60 and looks 20 years younger.

I really hate that the masses flock together to judge peoples physical appearances so vocally and publicly. I feel it often comes from a place of misunderstanding and insecurity which is a shame.

This movie was a fun little sleepy saturday film. I thought it wasn't super believable but neither are many rom-com plot lines. I enjoyed Joey King & Zac on screen together, I think they have great chemistry and Zac does well in comedies.

Romantic movies are great - when they work. Both Zac Efron and Nicole Kidman are also fine actors - when they have good materials to work with.

Unfortunately, this movie doesn't work for me. The premise is ok - it's par for the course for romantic movies, and having a big age difference isn't a problem - it can actually be done well: think, "Harold and Maud".

The issue is that I didn't really sense great chemistry between the two characters. The setup just didn't land. Everything seemed forced to go along with what the plot requires. I think a different script could have made a big difference.

Which is ironic, given a plot of the movie.

"A Family Affair" is simply not funny nor romantic. Joey KIng's character just comes across as bitter and hateful, rather than being a humorous obstacle to Efron's and Kidman's characters that she really needed to be.

If you've ever asked yourself who's had more procedures Zac or Nicole, this is your movie!!!

Firstly, it's really hard to tell a convincing love story without the ability to use facial expressions.

Secondly, the age gap doesn't come off as somehow he looks old and she looks freakishly young, so they meet somewhere in a creepy cosmetic surgery twilight zone where age knows no bounds.

Also, Zac looks way too much like Jack Frost from Rise of the Guardians as his super hero character...but the drawing was a better actor.

The daughter is great though and carried the whole movie, probably the only reason I didn't turn it off.

review_title: Nothing New But A Fun Watch
review_detailed_main: I actually enjoyed the chemistry and dynamics between Nicole Kidman and Zac Efron. The chemistry between Joey and Zac took a little bit longer to grow on me But about halfway through the movie, I really loved the give-and-take between the two of them. When as assistant, she learned to push back and he started to learn not to take people for granted. The scenery was absolutely gorgeous. Outside of the three leads, the supporting characters could've used a little bit more development, but overall it was a fun light romance, and I enjoyed it and would probably watch it again. I know the older woman, younger man dynamic isn't anything new but it was still a fun watch. And Kathy Bates is always a delight, no matter what she does.

I am a bit of a sucker for films that don't require much thought. I love romances and I am all for something light-hearted.

There is no chemistry between Kidman and Efron. Their interactions are uncomfortable and unbelieveable. Kidman is a great actress but this was not the right film for her talents.

I didn't mind the concept or the scrips and I could have happily watched this film multiple times if casting had worked better. Chemistry is so vital.

Joey King is good as is Kathy Bates but that is it.

If you want an age difference romance with leads that are credible and naturally pleasing I recommend The Idea of You with Anne Hathaway and Nicolas Galitzine - chemistry that is believable.

I'll skip all the jokes/complaints about presence of plastic in this movie, about missing (the other) chemistry, the main problem is (imho) that people misunderstand this movie. Whining about wrong cast, or missing chemistry of main couple is irrelevant, because it is not that rom-com, but a coming out of age movie. Main protagonist is Zara, not Chris and Brooke, they are just background players.

But even those they got somehow believable (one might argue) character arcs (depending on how you are feeling about Nicole and Zac. But I would say its more about "how you are feeling how Nicole and Zac look like", which seems to be much bigger issue for majority of people. I could understand that, but I find it funny for reviewers yelling "you should be aging gracefully", which feeling completely overwhelms their engagement with these characters. So they see them only how they look like, not how they behave, act. Which I find really meta.)

I think people would find couple of additional stars in their reviews, if they will stop thinking about this as a rom com movie.

It is not a groundbreaking piece of cinema, but it still has some interesting under tones, which are completely flying over audience heads. Which actually might be a problem of director, because it seems to be his "repeating offense". "The Last Five Years" suffers with same issue.

Netflix loves giving us content with high scrollability, stuff we can fill up that giant screen in front of the room while we occupy ourselves with doggo videos. Which may be fine because, like a deformed sun, it's best not to look at this dog directly. This new Netflix content exposes the sad, dark side of cosmetic surgery with a shocking look at Hollywood stars brought low by grotesque procedures.

Several self-absorbed (duh!) people go around swapping lovers in a plot straight out of Hallmark and/or an Evil Angel film. But that's not the bad part. The bad part is normalizing the appearance of these bizarre representations of humanity.

Someone dragged Kathy Bates into this mess.

For this being a Netflix movie, it has no business being as good as it is; I was extremely shocked and pleased.

Of course the formulaic romance "drama" is there so it's extremely predictable, but the comedy throughout is fairly decent.

Joey King was the real star of this, and she's pretty darn funny. Nicole Kidman and Zac Enron were good, nothing overly great or anything but not horrible so that's a good sign. Kathy Bates and Liza Koshy are nice additions, but don't nearly get enough screen time in my opinion.

Is this a must watch movie on Netflix? No.

But it is a decent feel good love story that you'll likely enjoy on a rainy weekend night.

The one star is for Kathy Bates. Everything about this movie is nonsense. How these garbage movies get made is beyond me. Netflix must have a pact with the devil. Every location looks like a set ... fake fake FAKE! Massive mansions with one piece of art and zero furniture. Nichole Kidman's face is so distracting and watching her kiss is like watching a sucker fish.

I wanted to laugh and since this is billed as a comedy, put it on. What a huge mistake. There wasn't one time where I laughed or chuckled or even smiled. Had lots of eye rolls though. There's no chemistry or believability to any of this.

If you look at this movie, as simply a romcom, then yes, you might be disappointed. But this movie is not really about the two characters in love, it's about the journey and growth of the 24-year old daughter, Zara, played by Joey King. The acting is actually quite good, Zara's growth as a young person realistic, and the movie did keep me engaged till the end (not the case with many movies these days) I gave it a 9 (rounded up from an 8.5) based on the genre it belongs to. For what it is, seen correctly, it's good. It's not meant to be Oscar worthy but it's definitely a good movie to stream on Netflix when there is not much else I find that I like.

review_title: Surprisingly less cheesy & more fun than I thought
review_detailed_main:
Okay, yes... Zac Efron has a different face now. Get over it. Once you do, it's just a fun flick. Nicole Kidman and Zac Efron are actually SO cute together in this film (which, btw, had one of the biggest laugh out loud moments I've seen in a romcom in a LONG time!). Overall, I was pleasantly surprised.

Joey King is adorable as ever in this movie. Her acting is so fitting for her personality and I genuinely enjoyed all she has to offer here. And Kathy Bates is a gem no matter what she does on screen. However, the kicker of this flick was the romance between NK & ZE! I literally squealed at one part because it was just so romantic and sweet. It frames an often criticized and overlooked part of our social structure where a single mother or a woman of a certain age isn't allowed to just be a woman, and I for one appreciate the spotlight. It was portrayed so well by these 2 beautiful, beautiful actors. Thank you for the couple hours of fun and romance. I had a blast watching!

Seriously, this would have been such a great film. The ONLY thing that saved this film is Joey King and Kathy Bates.

Nicole looks like a stone-faced unhuman and I think it's amazingly sad that so many beautiful women think they look younger and/or better with cosmetic surgery when in fact, we obviously notice and they never look better. Her hair color was horrid, her black eyebrows such a contrast that I couldn't stop looking at her instead of be involved in the movie! Zac looks like his face was frozen as well. It was very hard to continue watching it.....and again, if not for the amazing performance from Joey King, I probably would have turned it off. Kudos to her and Bates.

Just like Amazon's 'The Idea of You', this film visits the age-gap romance of the older woman (who's 'normal') with the younger man (who's famous).

Here, in this iteration, the plot is split between the character Zara Ford and her aspirations to produce films and using her celebrity boss, Chris Cole, to get there and her single mother, author/writer Brooke Harwood, who discovers an exciting connection with her daughter's boss.

Romance movies are, at its core, simple tropes and relies on those standard cliches. That's what we love about romance movies. What elevates the basic romance is the chemistry and overall plot that at least tries to throw some 'thing' to make it less typical and a tad more elevated or has decent acting.

Sadly, A Family Affair fails on many fronts. My rating is purely for Kathy Bates as the MIL to Kidman's character, whose husband has been gone 10+ years before, and the daughter, Zara Ford, played by Joey King, who is the PA to an obnoxious, shallow and selfish self-proclaimed movie star.

The number one problem are our leads. The age-gap, a trope in and of itself, is no the problem. There is absolutely zero chemistry between Kidman (who plays Brook Harwood) and Efron (who plays Chris Cole). Not to mention that their very faces are terribly distracting--in that, they've both had so much work done, you can't help but notice it and not really get past it. If there had been decent chemistry between them, all that could be forgiven to a degree.

The second issue is the acting. It's...rather terrible. Especially by Kidman and Efron, the latter whose ability is more Hallmark B-level skills. The only saving grace was King and Bates, who made it even remotely watchable.

I think the plot angle of King's character is actually a fun idea and King executes it brilliantly. She carries the movie. However, the rest of the plot is pretty miserable and nothing to really swoon at.

Also, because this movie came out so soon after Anne Hathaway's similar movie, which also lacked chemistry between its leads, it takes the general winds out of this movie. Ultimately, this did have potential as the plot isn't bad. Who knew that Efron and Kidman would suck and actually hurt the movie vs make it better?

If anything, watch it for Joey King and Kathy Bates.

review_title: Reasonably interesting drama of a May-October relationship.
It's a romcom with something else.

review_detailed_main:
I am used to watch cheap romance movies, I enjoy the predictability.

So I had high hopes with this one, but it seems that Netflix works on making cheaper Hallmark movies.

The main actors are so fake that they are distracting from the plot. And mostly Nicole Kidman is so fake! She doesn't even smile, and the filters they added to hide her wrinkles are just a joke. I would have loved this movie with another actress - there are so many beautiful natural actresses that also can act!

The daughter and grandma are saving the movie. I especially love the friendly grandmother, who of course also brings some wisdom and support.

Just for context, I'm a 64-year-old, single (twice divorced - never expected the 2nd one), straight male. And I enjoy a lot of different genres of movies, including 'chick flicks'.

Anyway, while this wasn't rip-roaringly funny, I did find it intentionally amusing in parts, and thought the story, though somewhat formulaic, was well executed. I also thought all of the performances were well done.

As far as the 'plastic' goes, I'm not a big fan of the type of plastic surgery a lot of celebrities have, and I have to wonder if it's all done by the same doctor, but in an industry where success is very largely dependent on looks, I can't blame the participants for trying to extend their careers by ridding themselves of the signs of aging. And for the most part, we can blame ourselves (the audience) for that, because we don't really want to see wrinkles and imperfections on the screen.

I liked the film and would recommend it for a pleasant feel-good experience.

Ok so Hollywood has existed for a long time, haven't producers and all the people involved in making films learned what works and what doesn't? Why would anyone think that viewers enjoy watching weird messed up plastic faces? I don't care how common plastic surgery might be IT DOES NOT LOOK GOOD, especially on screen, and especially for actors playing romantic roles it gives viewers that horrible cringe feeling, is not enjoyable. The human eye feels attracted to natural human looking faces not those weird looks. There are so so many actors and actresses with natural looking faces still, why cast these two? Why????

While I agree with comments regarding the plastic surgery and especially Nicole Kidman face hard to look at but I have no issue with Zac Effron face. The story is cute, and enjoying the age difference older woman romance. The daughter, Zara, is more of an entitled character than the movie star is.but perhaps this speaks to kids her age. It's just a rom com and it lives up to being a rom com, you know, fairy tale romance that seems too unreal but so fun and dreamy. I'm sorry about her face. Truly I am as she was so beautiful to begin with. Why they're all doing that plastic surgery is sad but the movie is still worth a rainy afternoon on the couch.

Most of what I saw in this movie has already, in just a few reviews, been said. For me? The script could have been reworked and maybe a decent movie could have come out of it. But the whole first 25 minutes of this movie concentrates on Chris Cole's mindless and terrible mental abuse of the character, Zara Ford. He is so absolutely horrible to her that I found myself thinking he is a woman hating man who never outgrew his teens.

Then, she finally, to my relief, quits the job and decides to move on. So far, there was a lot of material to work with.

Suddenly, Chris goes to Zara's house and meets her mother, Brooke Harwood. And here is where this movie fell off the rails in a way I have never seen in a Rom/Com. So, Chris, Played by Zac Efron, meets the Mom and within minutes they are kissing. I'm not sure I can do the mess of this script Justice here, but I'll try. When I found out Chris was supposed to be significantly younger than Brooke, I was stunned. NO WAY!! Suddenly, somehow, this child man grows up and falls in love with Brooke, the mother of Zara who spent 2 years being unspeakably abused by the man child. I'm sorry, what started out promising? Ended up unbelieavable.

So, Nicole Kidman played the mother who, for reasons I do not understand, falls in love in one scene with this man who has been verbally abusing her daughter for two years? Huh? She definitely should have passed on this movie! Two different actors and a massive rewrite might have changed the dynamic. Kathy Bates could not save this terrible movie. Miscast, badly written, poorly executed. The actress who played Zara was the only truly good actor in this film. Pass this one by. So sad to see so much talent wasted on a bad script, poor directing, and overall unbelievable story. I gave it a two, which it didn't deserve, because I just could not give so much wasted talent a one star. That makes as much sense as this movie!!! Just wish I could unsee this one!

review_title: This is not going to be a popular opinion but here we go..
review_detailed_main:
Imagine this, hard days work looking for a back ground watch and I stumble upon this. I ended up actually watching it. First to see if it was actually Zac Effron, then for the performances.

There are lots of comments about the "chemistry" being absent. Well kind of, but it isn't about the romance. It's about the 24 year old daughter. This is her story. For me it's about self involvement and the realisation that others exist. The "romance" is the catalyst, not the focus.

There are some lovely set pieces. It's a gentle watch, the main drama is from Zara everyone else is reasuringly mature, well except for Chris. Maybe that's the reason that people and critics suggest there isn't romance. That the chemistry is lacking. Of course Chris is smitten by Brooke, she's gorgeous and real. She isn't interested in celebrity or should I say Chris's Movie star status. Brooke is cautious, love happens when you least expect it.

There's nothing new in the plot, we all know how it will end. We all know the trajectory but how we get there is worth the watch. I loved it, the last scene is pure brilliance.

U can watch it as it's on Netflix. It's a very simple story. If u can get past the age-gap chemistry, it can be a good experience. U might have a problem with the plastic faces tho. I personally loved the love story and it was warm when there were intimate moments(not s**). Zoey did good acting. Zack and Nicole did a pretty convincing job in their scenes. I'm a sucker for love stories and i personally love them if the woman is older(comparatively). I don't have any problem with the cringe that some people felt. The idea is weird I agree. But if the characters can be seen as 2 people, the ride will be fantastic.

review_title: The mom made me angry the whole movie
What would you rather be: 52 and look 52, or 52 and look like a 28 year-old lizard?"
review_detailed_main:
This is a flood of mediocrity down uncanny valley.

Carrie Solomon shows no talent in screen writing, as the whole thing is stale. Much worse, however, is the message this movie seems to promote. Was this funded by a plastic surgery interest group? Seriously. There's no chemistry on screen between cast members. Both Nicole Kidman and Zac Efron look straight up scary, as if their Madame Tussauds wax figurines had come to life. Nicole is supposed to be very attractive in this, and why is her daughted so aggressively unattractive? Is that youth shaming? What justified casting Efron in the role? David duchovny, for eg, would have made the whole thing infinitely more interesting. Or, really, anyone without a wax figure.

Voting this up to a 7 (deserves a solid 6) to counter the wave of people voting it down on superficial judgements of actors faces rather than the film itself, which is a rather enjoyable story about the importance of letting the people in your life be happy rather than putting your own selfish feelings First. It's a coming of age film about the main character and Zac and Nicole are supporting characters, there to move the plot along. Yes it's a little far fetched, but if you follow the meaning rather than worrying about the unlikeliness of the situations there's a lot to enjoy and deep enough meaning to walk away fulfilled at the end. Not a rom com.

In order to gain her trust back, Zac visits Joey's house where he meets her mother who is played by Nicole Kidman. Somehow one way or another they fall in love and keep their secret from Joey till she finds out the truth about them. Kathy Bates played the mother/grandmother to the ladies who teaches them to be happy no matter who they meet or how old they are. Joe Roth produced this crappy movie. I got to say this was not the best romantic comedy movie, it started out funny with a good premise but I would not watch it again.

Do yourself a favor and carve out some time for romance and smilessssss.

This movie is another example. Is it great? No. But it's good and accomplishes what it sets out to: a great escape for an hour and a half from reality. It's enjoyable and offers scenes that will leave you laughing out loud. This is the kind of movie you'll notice you've been smiling while watching.

Nicole kidman is incredibly attractive and better than ever. Joey king turns in a great performance and Effron captures his character brilliantly portraying Chris Cole. This movie has A LOT of chemistry and is entertaining all the way through and that's what movies like this should be.

This Netflix original movie won't capture the world like 'Anyone But You' (excellent movie) but it will prove to be a successful rom-com.

Yes this movie does have some flaws but no enough so where it will distract you or take you out of it. Enjoy.

I've been reading several reviews to gauge general opinions because I genuinely love this film. However, unlike iconic romances with lines like "You had me at hello," this one is effective in its own right, despite some actors appearing to have undergone unnecessary cosmetic procedures. Zac Efron and Nicole Kidman, for instance, didn't need alterations to their already great faces. It's baffling why they chose to undergo such procedures when so few achieve the desired results.

Setting aside unrealistic expectations, this film offers a raw and emotionally satisfying romance. It centers on Zara (played by King) and a semi-narcissistic movie star who also happens to be her boss (played by Efron). She is his personal assistant aspiring to become a producer. Their dynamic shifts when Chris and Zara's mother, Brooke (played by Kidman), develop a romantic connection. Initially unsettling for Zara, this budding relationship evolves into something deeper, complicated by Chris's history of fleeting romances that Zara must manage on a regular basis.

The story ventures into the potential fallout of Brooke's heartbreak. Zara, who has always lived in Brooke's shadow as a famous writer, feels compelled to protect her mother despite their complex relationship. The situation intensifies with the involvement of Leila (played by Bates), Zara's grandmother, whose wisdom adds another layer of insight. Without realizing it, Zara has become the person she least admires, a self-centered woman who cares not about the feelings of anyone around her. Life has become all about her lately, and her mother and friends are suffering while she continues to focus on her own needs. Her best friend finally points out her selfishness and the drama intensifies.

Beyond the complexities, this film is a wonderfully intricate romantic comedy. Look past the cosmetic enhancements and appreciate it for the engaging love story it portrays.

Moreover, the dialogue is stilted and unnatural, filled with clichés and forced exposition that only serve to highlight the script's deficiencies. Conversations that should be poignant or revealing instead feel like they were written by someone who has never actually spoken to another human being.

The film's attempt at humor falls flat, with jokes that are either painfully outdated or simply unfunny. Dramatic moments are equally ineffective, often devolving into melodrama that elicits more eye rolls than tears.

A lavish American rom-com with a stellar cast to boast about is an easy pick for any moviegoer. The story is about a romance that blooms between a movie star and the mother of a young woman, facing complications in terms of having an affair at her age and resistance from the daughter.

It is a simple story that is clichéd, and you get a feeling of having seen it many times on screen before. These types of movies rely heavily on performances and execution. Here, the storytelling is monotone and it just doesn't go anywhere or have any high moment. The short runtime surely keeps you from getting bored, but you start to miss getting something more out of it.

Zac Efron in the lead is decent enough, and Nicole Kidman as the mother has an endearing presence. Joey King is good in her part, but even she has nothing much to perform. The costume designer deserves a special shout-out as all the characters look ravishing in the well made costumes.

A weak screenplay is surely a bummer for this film, taking it nowhere. Despite a prominent cast, they couldn't deliver an interesting movie. And if you feel it resembles 'The Idea of You', you are not alone; it has almost the exact same storyline.

You can watch it for the love of this genre as a timepass, but there's nothing to brag about."

review_title: A Heartfelt Romantic Comedy with a Stellar Cast
review_detailed_main:
A Family Affair is a delightful romantic comedy directed by Richard LaGravenese that explores the complexities of love, relationships, and family dynamics. Featuring a star-studded cast, the film offers a perfect blend of humor, romance, and heartfelt moments, making it a must-watch for fans of the genre.

Plot Summary 24-year-old Zara is tired of being underappreciated at her job as the personal assistant to self-absorbed Hollywood star Chris Cole.

A short time after Zara quits, Chris arrives at her house to offer her an assistant producer position but only finds Brooke, her mother, as Zara is out running errands. As he decides to wait for her, he and Brooke hit it off. By the time Zara returns, she unknowingly walks in on them having sex.

Zara is promised that it won't happen again, but Chris invites Brooke to dinner. Before they realize it, Zara's boss is having a secret romantic relationship with her widowed mother

Writing and Execution Richard LaGravenese, known for his knack for blending romance with genuine emotion, delivers a screenplay that is both witty and poignant. The dialogue is sharp and often humorous, capturing the awkwardness and charm of unexpected romantic situations. The story's pacing is well-balanced, allowing for both comedic moments and deeper emotional beats to resonate with the audience.

The film's plot, while rooted in familiar romantic comedy tropes, is elevated by its focus on family dynamics and the intergenerational impact of relationships. LaGravenese's direction ensures that the film remains engaging, with each scene contributing meaningfully to the development of the characters and the story.

Acting Nicole Kidman, as always, delivers a nuanced performance as Joey's mother. Her portrayal is both graceful and relatable, bringing depth to a character that could easily have been one-dimensional. Kidman's chemistry with Zac Efron is unexpectedly delightful, adding a layer of complexity to the romantic dynamics in the film.

Zac Efron shines as Joey's boss, balancing charm and vulnerability with ease. His comedic timing is impeccable, and he brings a sincerity to his role that makes his character's journey believable and endearing.

Joey King, as the protagonist, is the heart of the film. Her performance is vibrant and earnest, capturing the confusion and excitement of navigating unexpected romantic territory. King's interactions with both Kidman and Efron are compelling, making the love triangle feel authentic and engaging.

Kathy Bates and Liza Koshy, in supporting roles, provide additional layers of humor and warmth. Bates' portrayal of a wise and witty family matriarch adds gravitas to the story, while Koshy's energetic presence brings a modern, relatable edge to the film.

Cinematography and Music The cinematography by Maryse Alberti complements the film's tone perfectly. The vibrant, picturesque settings enhance the romantic atmosphere, while the more intimate scenes are shot with a warmth that underscores the film's emotional core.

The musical score, composed by Alexandre Desplat, is both whimsical and touching, adding an extra layer of emotion to the film. The soundtrack features a mix of contemporary tracks and classic tunes, perfectly aligning with the film's themes of love and nostalgia.

Conclusion A Family Affair is a charming and heartfelt romantic comedy that stands out for its excellent performances, sharp writing, and thoughtful direction. Richard LaGravenese has crafted a film that, while rooted in traditional romantic comedy elements, explores deeper themes of family and the lasting impact of love.

Nicole Kidman, Zac Efron, and Joey King lead a stellar cast, each bringing their unique strengths to the film. The result is a delightful and emotionally resonant movie that will leave audiences laughing, crying, and reflecting on the importance of family and the complexities of love. A Family Affair is a refreshing addition to the romantic comedy genre and a testament to the enduring appeal of well-crafted, character-driven storytelling.

Netflix is known to put out a lot of terrible, cheesy movies out there so that people have something to have in the background while they do chores. The formula is that it cannot be interesting enough to prevent you from multitasking, yet the visuals/soundtrack/plot have to draw enough attention so that the half of your brain that is not folding laundry is not bored enough to look for something else.

Usually this end up in some terribly uninspired movies that don't have a single scene without a cliché. But this time around, they came up with something that is actually enjoyable.

Of course, this is not an A24 or Villeneuve movie that, while being accessible, still puts the cast in a position to actually act, and the cinematography and soundtrack are built with a concept in mind. The sets are the usual LA stereotype: Beaches, huge backyards with views, McMansions, fancy restaurants, etc. The soundtrack is a collage of small clips from whatever is on the Spotify top 100 playlist.

But, given its context, I found the movie very entertaining. The plot isn't anything new - just a remodeling of the classic love triangle replacing the romantic edges by other types of love. And since a good chunk of the movie is either slightly melancholic or teenage style love scenes, there isn't too much acting going on. But there is a layer to it that separates this movie from others. Efron's character is so much of a caricature that I refuse to believe it wasn't written sardonically, which leads to some actually funny scenes. In contrast, Kidman is playing someone that we all have met - of course, except for the money - someone who faces a series of challenges at a point in their lives that they can't afford to actually deal with them, so they postpone themselves for so long that they get so caught up with life that they forget to live it. The main character, player by Joey King, is not as remarkable, but is still a nice depiction of the problems a lot of young people face today: the road to your dreams feel too long and hard, staying where you are isn't special enough, and leaving it all behind is too scary and uncomfortable.

Overall, not a movie I would invite friends over to rewatch. But I don't think that was the purpose of the movie in the first place. This is the cinema equivalent of that half-tray of lasagna that your mother left for you, and you keep it in the freezer for an evening you are too tired to cook, but still need something that makes you feel good.

Chris Cole (Zac Efron) is a famous movie star. 24 year old Zara Ford (Joey King) has been his suffering assistant for two years and he refuses to make her more than a gopher. Kidman's character is painfully out of touch, behaving more like an overgrown adolescent than the accomplished actress she is. Watching her navigate this cinematic disaster is akin to witnessing a distinguished professor trying to engage in playground antics. Her daughter Zara, played to ear-splitting perfection by Joey King, alternates between whining and shouting, bringing the concept of spoiled brat to new heights.

Then there's Zac Efron, who seems completely out of his depth as the caricature of a Hollywood star. He tries to embody the role, but unfortunately, his efforts only highlight the film's many shortcomings. And let's not forget his latest look - Efron's transformation post-surgery leaves him resembling David Hasselhoff in his prime, which, while weirdly attractive, does nothing to bolster his performance.

The visual spectacle doesn't stop with Efron. Nicole Kidman's waxy visage and her peculiar, almost radioactive yellow hair color are a distraction. It's a pity that an artist of her caliber demeaned herself by taking on this role, especially when her appearance alone adds an unintended layer of absurdity to every scene she graces.

PS as a side note to the review titled "FYI", and the reason why Efron had his surgery, were you there to witness his accident? I hear so many people "justifying" a nose job claiming they broke it... And Kidman looks great for her age, but she certainly doesn't shine for the wisdom she should have achieved - why should eternal adolescence be pursued at all costs? I watched A Family Affair a couple of days after The Idea of You. Both stories feature a romantic fling between an older female and a younger celebrity male, with the age difference being 16 years in both cases. Both mothers also have a daughter, who comes in between them and their new admirers. While The Idea of You is commendable in its attempt to convey the challenges that such a coupling brings, A Family Affair prefers to keep it light and vacuous.

Unlike most rom-coms where the eventual couple act coy, misread each other's intentions, get involved with a third party, develop their bond over time, have a crisis near the final hurdle etc., A Family Affair does away with all of that by having Chris, Efron's movie star, jump Brooke's, Kidman's widow mom, bones on the very first time they meet. At this point, we know little about Chris and even less about Brooke. Without any suspense or believability about their pairing, I found it wholly impossible to be invested in their staying together.

Besides their frozen faces, flat acting and abject absence of any sexual tension, Efron and Kidman portray one-dimensional characters that don't evoke sympathy. The daughter, Zara, is especially on-the-nose with her incessant whining and self-absorbed opposition to her mom dating her celebrity boss. Not even Kathy Bates as Grandma could save this dumpster fire. Why is she even in this? A good rom-com makes us root for the couple as corny as the ending may be; A Family Affair has zero stakes and utterly fails as a rom-com.

review_title: Finally! A Wonderful Rom-Com That's Not Embarrassing to Watch!
review_detailed_main:
Firstly, I don't understand the negative reviews (particularly the ones bagging on the physical features of the cast... Why do these reviewers feel it essential to translate their own insecurities onto others-especially for a movie review? Side note: if their own features were put on blast in response to their ridiculous criticism, I'm sure they'd actually correspond a review worth actual content). Now, onto the meat and potatoes of this review...

The trio had incredible chemistry and Zac Efron's comedic timing in his line deliver was incredible! Kathy Bates also shined in her role and her relationship with Nicole Kidman was beautiful. As I am someone who just completed being in their 20's, I felt that Joey King's portrayal and how her character was written, perfectly displayed the reality of an up-and-coming adult struggling to not only find her place in the work world, but also the sometimes rough reality of the new relationship we transition to with our parents as adult children.

As for the film's faults, there isn't many. Liza Koshy's character was a bit rough during her first introduction but did become a likable character towards the end of the film. I felt that her character was more Liza playing herself rather than the actual character. I do wish there was a scene between the characters of Joey King, Liza Koshy, and Sherry Cola to make them a friendship trio. It felt like a smooth way to make condense amount of character groups and become a bit more cohesive to watch and follow their connections to Zara.

The other fault was the in-your-face product placement. I get it-movies need funding to start with and product placement is a great way to do it! But holy smokes did it feel like one long commercial full of products! I will say, a lot of the highlighted items are actually good, but that is besides the point. The placement of the labels was very unnatural and became distracting in the scenes (one of the strongest was Chris Cole using Kodiak and King Arthur flour together while cooking-which doesn't make any sense because you do not need flour to make Kodiak anything since it's already in the mix... but I will say both of these products are great and I have both in my kitchen right now).

In all truth, I was not expecting to love this movie and be as entrained as I was to the point of eye-watering laughter. I've noticed a lot Netflix Rom-Coms recently have often miss their mark with lazy writing, subpar acting, and lack of chemistry between characters. 'A Family Affair' is a movie that doesn't have a backlash of second-hand embarrassment for the viewer. I will say that what sold me on even watching this movie was Zac Efron. I've never seen a movie I didn't enjoy of his and I believe it is not only because of his incredible acting, but his choice to be in such greatly written movies and not to be in the ones that might miss the mark.

Overall, this is a movie I would gladly watch again and recommend to anyone looking for a feel good Rom-Com that doesn't make you regret watching it.

Thank you for the lovely watch!

review_title: A Family Affair: A Lacanian Romp Through the Unconscious
review_detailed_main:
A Family Affair, masquerading as a lighthearted romantic comedy, offers a surprisingly potent exploration of Lacanian psychoanalysis. The film delves into the complexities of desire, the construction of the self, and the ever-present dance of power within the family unit.

Central to this exploration is the concept of "lack." One character grapples with loss, creating a void in their established sense of self. Enter another character, brimming with youthful energy and a captivating presence. This character disrupts the existing dynamic, forcing everyone to confront their own desires and their place within the family structure.

Lacanian theory posits three realms: the Real, the Imaginary, and the Symbolic. A Family Affair masterfully utilizes humor to explore these concepts in a relatable way. The laughter serves as a gateway, allowing audiences to engage with complex psychoanalytic ideas without feeling overwhelmed.

The film cleverly subverts traditional narratives around family roles. The characters grapple with societal expectations and the internal yearning for something more. This creates a fascinating tension, forcing us to question the very nature of desire and its role within family relationships.

A Family Affair is more than just a movie; it's a cinematic Rorschach test. It compels us to confront the complexities of the unconscious mind, the fluidity of family dynamics, and the ever-present dance of desire that shapes our lives. Prepare to be surprised, to laugh, and to have your understanding of family relationships playfully challenged.

A Family Affair, starring Nicole Kidman, Zac Efron, Joey King, and Kathy Bates, had the potential to deliver a compelling story with its star-studded cast, but unfortunately, it fell flat.

How I Found It: The movie didn't hold my attention and felt like it was plodding along without much direction. I kept waiting for it to pick up or offer some emotional depth, but it never did. It lacked the spark and warmth that make rom-coms enjoyable, leaving me disappointed.

Nicole Kidman: I usually find Nicole Kidman captivating on screen, but her performance here was underwhelming. Her character annoyed me, particularly because of the questionable choices she made-never put a man before your child! It felt like a waste of her talent, and I couldn't connect with her role.

Zac Efron: While I've enjoyed Zac Efron in films like New Year's Eve and Baywatch, this role just didn't work for me. It's not entirely his fault, but he essentially played a version of himself, which came across as dull. His character lacked the charm or complexity needed to stand out.

Joey King: The saving grace of the movie. Joey King delivered a captivating performance, and I found myself enjoying every scene she was in. She brought energy and authenticity that the rest of the film lacked.

Kathy Bates: Kathy Bates is always a joy to watch, and her scenes were no exception. She brought a touch of magic and gravitas to the movie, even if the script didn't give her much to work with.

Best scene for me: the Christmas scene when they're all at the cabin. This scene delivers the growth that was sorely lacking until this point.

Overall: The film is primarily a series of glimpses of Kidman and Efron as a happy, affectionate couple, but it doesn't go beyond surface-level storytelling. It's essentially a rom-com without the sizzle or the warm glow that makes the genre so comforting. Instead, it felt a little sad and lacking in heart.

Final Thoughts: Despite the strong cast, A Family Affair fails to deliver. It's not the worst movie I've seen, but it's far from memorable. If you're looking for a light-hearted rom-com, this one may leave you wanting more.

review_title: Not a new story, but wonderfully done.
review_detailed_main:
Joey King plays Zara, daughter to Nicole Kidman as Brooke, and employee of Zac Efron who plays conceited actor Chris Cole. Zara is unhappy that Cole is not making good his early promises about her employment with him, and when Cole and her Mum meet everything breaks down.

It's a typical family type film where the daughter is unhappy about the parent, and when a man becomes involved, especially one renowned as a love rat, she is understandably upset and falls out with her Mum. Mother and daughter both turn to grandma Ford played by Kathy Bates.

However there are twists and turns along the way, the usual misunderstandings and hurt feelings, and the inevitable mish mash of boiled emotions coming to a fitting crescendo.

But, while this is not a new story it's a new presentation. Joey King is amazing, she goes from better to brilliant. Nicole Kidman is her normal excellent self. Kathy Bates...almost a legend in her own right. And Zac Efron, I never would have believed that I could say he played a great part.

Together the cast, the writer and the director delivered a brilliantly told story with such amazing connections between all actors, that it was a joy to watch such a simple story.

I loved this film and if you like romantic comedies do not miss it. A solid 8 from me.

I enjoyed this! There was good chemistry and affinity among all the actors. The scenery and locations were beautiful, especially Brooke's home. Nicole Kidman brings the loveliness as an author and single mom, and Zac Efron's boyish charm pairs well with her feminine grace.

The film centers on their attraction, which evolves into more than just a sexual fling. Her daughter, though, is Efron's personal assistant and he's a celebrity mega-hunk. We learn at the beginning that he doesn't have a great track record with commitment.

What made this film unique is that Kidman's character is 16 years older than him. So, this film is part of a recent spate of releases with other over-40 actresses, including Brooke Shields and Anne Hathaway, demonstrating that older women can still be vibrant, beautiful and sexually appealing.

That's a dramatic sea change for Hollywood because the entertainment industry has been notorious for sending older actresses out to pasture, or relegating them to unattractive supporting roles. In this film and the others, they play moms who are not supporting actors. They are the leads, alongside, not behind, younger actresses playing their daughters.

Older moms are depicted as having exciting second acts. No longer relegated to brandishing knitting needles and making lemonade at family BBQs, these women have great careers and vibrant sex lives.

And I gotta thank Nicole Kidman for helping get that message out there and you gotta see this film because it's sweet and uplifting and it'll make you feel all warm and cozy inside.
